message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trisomy 13, also known as Patau syndrome, is associated with multiple abnormalities such as cutis aplasia. None of the other options are associated with trisomy 13. Optic glioma is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, cystic hygroma can be a sign of Turner syndrome, and prominent occiput can be a sign of Down syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased nuchal translucency and decreased levels of beta-hCG and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A suggest a high risk for chromosomal abnormalities. Trisomy of chromosome 13 is associated with cutis aplasia, while optic glioma is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, cystic hygroma is associated with Turner syndrome, and a prominent occiput is associated with Down syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trisomy 13 is also known as Patau Syndrome and is associated with cutis aplasia, which is a condition where a section of skin is missing or doesn't form properly. Optic glioma is associated with Neurofibromatosis type 1, cystic hygroma is associated with Turner Syndrome, and prominent occiput is associated with Down Syndrome. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) cutis aplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trisomy 13 is associated with a variety of physical abnormalities, and cutis aplasia (failure of skin formation) is one of them. Optic glioma is associated with neurofibromatosis and cystic hygroma is associated with Turner syndrome. Prominent occiput is not commonly associated with trisomy 13.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trisomy of chromosome 13 is associated with several malformations, including cutis aplasia, which is a condition where there are areas of missing skin. The other options listed are associated with different conditions or chromosomal abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of increased nuchal translucency, decreased β-hCG concentration, and decreased levels of pregnancy-associated plasma protein A suggests a risk for trisomy of chromosome 13. Cutis aplasia is a common finding in this condition. Optic glioma is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, while cystic hygroma is associated with Turner syndrome. A prominent occiput is a feature of hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trisomy 13 is also known as Patau syndrome, which is associated with numerous physical abnormalities including cutis aplasia (areas of absent skin), as well as neurologic abnormalities such as optic glioma. Cystic hygroma is associated with Turner syndrome and lymphatic malformations, and a prominent occiput is not typically associated with trisomy 13.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trisomy of chromosome 13 is also known as Patau syndrome, which is associated with cutis aplasia, among other anomalies. Optic glioma is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. Cystic hygroma is commonly associated with Turner syndrome. Prominent occiput is not typically associated with Patau syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased nuchal translucency, decreased β-hCG concentration, and decreased levels of pregnancy-associated plasma protein A are all associated with trisomy 13. Cutis aplasia is a feature of trisomy 13, while optic glioma, cystic hygroma, and prominent occiput are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Trisomy 13 is also known as Patau syndrome, which is associated with various abnormalities including cutis aplasia, cleft lip and palate, polydactyly, and heart defects. Option A (optic glioma) is more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. Option C (cystic hygroma) is more commonly associated with Turner syndrome. Option D (prominent occiput) is not a common manifestation of trisomy 13.
